sun: Its brittle shell occasionally spouts intense flames that circulate throughout its body.

sun: Although its legs are short, its rugged hooves prevent it from slipping, even on icy ground.

sun: This Pokémon is said to live in a world on the reverse side of ours, where common knowledge is distorted and strange.

sun: Shiny particles are released from its wings like a veil. It is said to represent the crescent moon.
moon: Those who sleep holding Cresselia's feather are assured of joyful dreams. It is said to represent the crescent moon.

sun: When the water warms, they inflate the flotation sac on their heads and drift languidly on the sea in packs.
moon: It drifts in warm seas. It always returns to where it was born, no matter how far it may have drifted.

sun: It is born with a wondrous power that lets it bond with any kind of Pokémon.
moon: It starts its life with a wondrous power that permits it to bond with any kind of Pokémon.

sun: It chases people and Pokémon from its territory by causing them to experience deep, nightmarish slumbers.
moon: It can lull people to sleep and make them dream. It is active during nights of the new moon.

sun: It can dissolve toxins in the air to instantly transform ruined land into a lush field of flowers.
moon: The blooming of Gracidea flowers confers the power of flight upon it. Feelings of gratitude are the message it delivers.

sun: It can dissolve toxins in the air to instantly transform ruined land into a lush field of flowers.
moon: The blooming of Gracidea flowers confers the power of flight upon it. Feelings of gratitude are the message it delivers.

sun: According to the legends of Sinnoh, this Pokémon emerged from an egg and shaped all there is in this world.
moon: It is told in mythology that this Pokémon was born before the universe even existed.

sun: This Pokémon brings victory. It is said that Trainers with Victini always win, regardless of the type of encounter.
moon: When it shares the infinite energy it creates, that being's entire body will be overflowing with power.

sun: Being exposed to sunlight makes its movements swifter. It uses vines more adeptly than its hands.
moon: They photosynthesize by bathing their tails in sunlight. When they are not feeling well, their tails droop.

sun: It moves along the ground as if sliding. Its swift movements befuddle its foes, and it then attacks with a vine whip.
moon: When it gets dirty, its leaves can't be used in photosynthesis, so it always keeps itself clean.

sun: It only gives its all fighting against strong opponents who are not fazed by the glare from Serperior's noble eyes.
moon: It can stop its opponents'movements with just a glare. It takes in solar energy and boosts it internally.

sun: It can deftly dodge its foe's attacks while shooting fireballs from its nose. It roasts berries before it eats them.
moon: It loves to eat roasted berries, but sometimes it gets too excited and burns them to a crisp.

sun: The more it eats, the more fuel it has to make the fire in its stomach stronger. This fills it with even more power.
moon: When its internal fire flares up, its movements grow sharper and faster. When in trouble, it emits smoke.

sun: It can throw a fire punch by setting its fists on fire with its fiery chin. It cares deeply about its friends.
moon: It has mastered fast and powerful fighting moves. It grows a beard of fire.

sun: The scalchop on its stomach isn't just used for battle--it can be used to break open hard berries as well.
moon: It fights using the scalchop on its stomach. In response to an attack, it retaliates immediately by slashing.

sun: Strict training is how it learns its flowing double-scalchop technique.
moon: As a result of strict training, each Dewott learns different forms for using the scalchops.

sun: In the time it takes a foe to blink, it can draw and sheathe the seamitars attached to its front legs.
moon: One swing of the sword incorporated in its armor can fell an opponent. A simple glare from one of them quiets everybody.

sun: Using food stored in cheek pouches, they can keep watch for days. They use their tails to communicate with others.
moon: Extremely cautious, one of them will always be on the lookout, but it won't notice a foe coming from behind.

sun: Using luminescent matter, it makes its eyes and body glow and stuns attacking opponents.
moon: When they see an enemy, their tails stand high, and they spit the seeds of berries stored in their cheek pouches.

sun: Because it doesn’t yelp, it’s extremely popular with Trainers who live in apartment buildings.
moon: The long fur surrounding its face functions as radar, enabling it to probe the condition of its battle opponents.

sun: Its dense black fur grows continuously. The high cost of keeping its hard fur properly groomed makes this a troublesome Pokémon to train.
moon: This Pokémon obeys its master’s orders faithfully. However, it refuses to listen to anything said by a person it doesn’t respect.

sun: Intelligent, good-natured, and valiant, it’s a trustworthy partner on rescue teams.
moon: With this wise Pokémon, there could be no concern that it would ever attack people. Some parents even trust it to babysit.

sun: Its cute act is a ruse. When victims let down their guard, they find their items taken, It attacks with sharp claws.
moon: They steal from people for fun, but their victims can't help but forgive them. Their deceptively cute act is perfect.

sun: Their beautiful form comes from the muscles they have developed. They run silently in the night.
moon: Stealthily, it sneaks up on its target, striking from behind before its victim has a chance to react.

sun: It shares the leaf on its head with weary-looking Pokémon. These leaves are known to relieve stress.
moon: It's good at finding berries and gathers them from all over. It's kind enough to share them with friends.

sun: It attacks enemies with strikes of its thorn-covered tail. This Pokémon is wild tempered.
moon: Ill tempered, it fights by swinging its barbed tail around wildly. The leaf growing on its head is very bitter.

sun: Very intelligent, it roasts berries before eating them. It likes to help people.
moon: This Pokémon lives in caves in volcanoes. The fire within the tuft on its head can reach 600 degrees Fahrenheit.

sun: A flame burns inside its body. It scatters embers from its head and tail to sear its opponents.
moon: When it gets excited, embers rise from its head and tail and it gets hot. For some reason, it loves sweets.

sun: The water stored inside the tuft on its head is full of nutrients. It waters plants with it using its tail.
moon: The water stored inside the tuft on its head is full of nutrients. Plants that receive its water grow large.

sun: The high-pressure water expelled from its tail is so powerful, it can destroy a concrete wall.
moon: It prefers places with clean water. When its tuft runs low, it replenishes it by siphoning up water with its tail.

sun: This Pokémon appears before people and Pokémon who are having nightmares and eats those dreams.
moon: It eats the dreams of people and Pokémon. When it eats a pleasant dream, it expels pink-colored mist.

sun: The mist emanating from their foreheads is packed with the dreams of people and Pokémon.
moon: The dream mist coming from its forehead changes into many different colors depending on the dream that was eaten.

sun: This very forgetful Pokémon will wait for a new order from its Trainer even though it already has one.
moon: These Pokémon live in cities. They are accustomed to people. Flocks often gather in parks and plazas.

sun: Many people believe that, deep in the forest where Tranquill live, there is a peaceful place where there is no war.
moon: No matter where in the world it goes, it knows where its nest is, so it never gets seperated from its Trainer.

sun: Males swing their head plumage to threaten opponents. The females' flying abilities surpass those of the males.
moon: Males have plumage on their heads. They will never let themselves feel close to anyone other than their Trainers.

sun: When thunderclouds cover the sky, it will appear. It can catch lightning with its mane and store the electricity.
moon: Its mane shines when it discharges electricity. They use the frequency and rhythm of these flashes to communicate.

sun: When this ill-tempered Pokémon runs wild, it shoots lightning from its mane in all directions.
moon: They have lightning-like movements. When Zebstrika run at full speed, the sound of thunder reverberates.

sun: Born deep within the ground, it compares itself with similar species, such as Geodude and Carbink, to settle which has the hardest body.
moon: The hexagonal cavity is its ear. It walks in the direction of sounds it hears, but if the sounds cease, it panics and topples over.

sun: Its orange crystal is a mass of energy. Just one crystal fragment would provide enough fuel for a hundred dump trucks.
moon: It explores caves in search of underground water. It’s not comfortable around water, so this Pokémon takes great care in lapping it up.

sun: The blasts of energy it makes from sunbeams have terrifying power. However, it’s not able to fire its blasts at night or on rainy days.
moon: Known for its hefty horsepower, this Pokémon is a popular partner for construction workers.

sun: Its habitat is dark forests and caves. It emits  ultrasonic waves from its nose to learn about its surroundings.
moon: The heart-shaped mark left on a body after a Woobat has been attached to it is said to bring good fortune.

sun: It shakes its tail vigorously when it emits ultrasonic waves strong enough to reduce concrete to rubble.
moon: Anyone who comes into contact with the ultrasonic waves emitted by a courting male experiences a positive mood shift.

sun: It makes its way swiftly through the soil by putting both claws together and rotating at high speed.
moon: By spinning its body, it can dig straight through the ground at a speed of 30 mph.

sun: It can help in tunnel construction. Its drill has evolved into steel strong enough to bore through iron plates.
moon: More than 300 feet below the surface, they build mazelike nests. Their activity can be destructive to subway tunnels.

sun: Using the feelers on its ears, it can tell how someone is feeling or when an egg might hatch.
moon: It touches others with the feelers on its ears, using the sound of their heartbeats to tell how they are feeling.

sun: Using the feelers on its ears, it can tell how someone is feeling or when an egg might hatch.
moon: It touches others with the feelers on its ears, using the sound of their heartbeats to tell how they are feeling.

sun: These Pokémon appear at building sites and help out with construction. They always carry squared logs.
moon: Always carrying squared logs, they help out with construction. As they grow, they carry bigger logs.

sun: With strengthened bodies, they skillfully wield steel beams to take down buildings.
moon: This Pokémon is so muscular and strongly built that even a group of wrestlers could not make it budge an inch.

sun: It is thought that Conkeldurr taught humans how to make concrete more than 2,000 years ago.
moon: Rather than rely on force, they master moves that utilize the centrifugal force of spinning concrete.

sun: By vibrating its cheeks, it emits sound waves imperceptible to humans and warns others of danger.
moon: By vibrating its cheeks, it emits sound waves imperceptible to humans. It uses the rhythm of these sounds to talk.

sun: When they vibrate the bumps on their heads, they can make waves in water or earthquake-like vibrations on land.
moon: It lives in the water and on land. It uses its long, sticky tongue to immobilize its opponents.

sun: It increases the power of its punches by vibrating the bumps on its fists. It can turn a boulder to rubble with one punch.
moon: They shoot paralyzing liquid from their head bumps. They use vibration to hurt their opponents.

sun: When it tightens its belt, it becomes stronger. Wild Throh use vines to weave their own belts
moon: When it encounters a foe bigger than itself, it wants to throw it. It changes belts as it gets stronger.

sun: Desiring the strongest karate chop, they seclude themselves in mountains and train without sleeping.
moon: Tying their belts gets them pumped and makes their punches more destructive. Disturbing their training angers them.

sun: This Pokémon makes clothes for itself. It chews up leaves and sews them with sticky thread extruded from its mouth.
moon: Since this Pokémon makes its own clothes out of leaves, it is a popular mascot for fashion designers.

sun: Forests where Swadloon live have superb foliage because the nutrients they make from fallen leaves nourish the plant life.
moon: It protects itself from the cold by wrapping up in leaves. It stays on the move, eating leaves in forests.

sun: Upon finding a small Pokémon, it weaves clothing for it from leaves by using the sticky silk secreted from its mouth.
moon: It keeps its eggs warm with heat from fermenting leaves. It also uses leaves to make warm wrappings for Sewaddle.

sun: It discovers what is going on around it by using the feelers on its head and tail. It is brutally aggressive.
moon: Its bite injects a potent poison, enough to paralyze large bird Pokémon that try to prey on it.

sun: Protected by a hard shell, it spins its body like a wheel and crashes furiously into its enemies.
moon: It is usually motionless, but when attacked, it rotates at high speed and then crashes into its opponent.

sun: It clasps its prey with the claws on its neck until it stops moving. Then it finishes it off with deadly poison.
moon: With quick movements, it chases down its foes, attacking relentlessly with its horns until it prevails.

sun: When it finds others of its kind, they all stick together. When enough of them have collected, the mass resembles a cumulonimbus cloud.
moon: Pillows and beds stuffed with cotton exhaled by Cottonee are soft and puffy, light and airy— altogether top quality.

sun: It rides on the wind and slips into people’s homes. After it has turned a room into a cotton- filled mess, it giggles to itself and takes off.
moon: This Pokémon appears, riding upon the wind. But if the wind gusts up, it’ll blow the cotton on this Pokémon’s head clean off.

sun: Although the leaves on its head are bitter enough to cause dizziness, they provide relief from weariness—even more so when boiled.
moon: By pruning the leaves on its head with regularity, this Pokémon can be grown into a fine plump shape.

sun: No matter how much time and money is spent raising it, its flowers are the most beautiful when they bloom in the wild.
moon: As soon as it finds a male to be its partner, the beautiful flower on its head darkens, droops, and withers away.

sun: Red- and blue-striped Basculin are very violent and always fighting. They are also remarkably tasty.
moon: Red and blue Basculin usually do not get along, but sometimes members of one school mingle with the other's school.

sun: Red- and blue-striped Basculin are very violent and always fighting. They are also remarkably tasty.
moon: Red and blue Basculin usually do not get along, but sometimes members of one school mingle with the other's school.

sun: It submerges itself in sand and moves as if swimming. This wise behavior keeps its enemies from finding it and maintains its temperature.
moon: It conceals itself in the sand and chomps down on the legs of any prey that unwarily walk over it. Its favorite food is Trapinch.

sun: They move in groups of a few individuals. A female is often the leader of the group, and the males will gather food.
moon: Thanks to the special membrane covering its eyes, it can see its surroundings clearly, even in the middle of the night.

sun: Its unique faculty of sight can detect small prey more than 30 miles away, even in the midst of a sandstorm.
moon: After clamping down with its powerful jaws, it twists its body around to rip its prey in half.

sun: Darumaka's droppings are hot, so people used to put them in their clothes to keep themselves warm.
moon: When it sleeps, it pulls its limbs into its body and its internal fire goes down to 1,100 F.

sun: When one is injured in a fierce battle, it hardens into a stone-like form. Then it meditates and sharpens its mind.
moon: Its internal fire burns at 2,500° F, making enough power that it can destroy a dump truck with one punch.

sun: When one is injured in a fierce battle, it hardens into a stone-like form. Then it meditates and sharpens its mind.
moon: Its internal fire burns at 2,500° F, making enough power that it can destroy a dump truck with one punch.

sun: It uses an up-tempo song and dance to drive away the bird Pokémon that prey on its flower seeds
moon: Arid regions are their habitat. They move rhythmically, making a sound similar to maracas.

sun: It makes a hole in a suitable rock. If that rock breaks, the Pokémon remains agitated until it locates a replacement.
moon: When it finds a stone of a suitable size, it secretes a liquid from its mouth to open up a hole to crawl into.

sun: It possesses legs of enormous strength, enabling it to carry heavy slabs for many days, even when crossing arid land.
moon: Competing for territory, Crustle fight viciously. The one whose boulder is broken is the loser of the battle.

sun: Its skin has a rubbery elasticity, so it can reduce damage by defensively pulling its skin up to its neck.
moon: Proud of its sturdy skull, it suddenly headbutts everything, but its weight makes it unstable, too.

sun: It pulls up its shed skin to protect itself while it kicks. The bigger the crest, the more respected it is.
moon: It can smash concrete blocks with its kicking attacks. The one with the biggest crest is the group leader.

sun: The guardians of an ancient city, they use their psychic power to attack enemies that invade their territory.
moon: The guardians of an ancient city, they always fly the same route while keeping watch for invaders.

sun: These Pokémon arose from the spirits of people interred in graves. Each retains memories of its former life.
moon: Each of them carries a mask that used to be its face when it was human. Sometimes they look at it and cry.

sun: It has been said that they swallow those who get too close and turn them into mummies. They like to eat gold nuggets.
moon: Grave robbers who mistake them for real coffins and get too close end up trapped inside their bodies.

sun: Based on studies of its skeletal structure, it can apparently dive to ocean depths of over half a mile.
moon: Reputed to be the ancestor of most turtle Pokémon, it lived in warm seas approximately a hundred million years ago.

sun: It constructed its sturdy shell by crunching and swallowing the hard shells or bones of its prey.
moon: Active both on land and in the sea, this Pokémon drags its land-based prey into the water to finish it off.

sun: It is the ancestor of all bird Pokémon. Archen itself could not actually fly but moved by hopping from treetop to treetop.
moon: To all appearances flightless, it was able to glide down from tall treetops to snag its prey.

sun: Although apparently able to fly, they tended to run along the ground, averaging speeds of roughly 25 mph.
moon: They hunted in flocks. When one Archeops had the prey cornered, another would swoop on it.

sun: Unsanitary places are what they like best. They can be spotted in Alola, often with Grimer in hot pursuit.
moon: It gorges on trash until its stomach is full. Then it belches toxic gas. An unlucky whiff of gas will put a person in the hospital.

sun: Beware the poisonous liquid it shoots from its right arm. If even a little of it gets on you, you’ll experience the effects of the unidentified toxin.
moon: For a time, their numbers increased explosively in Alola. Since the arrival of Grimer, their population has decreased dramatically.

sun: It changes so it looks like its foe, tricks it, and then uses that opportunity to flee.
moon: To protect themselves from danger, they hide their true identities by transforming into people and Pokémon.

sun: Each has the ability to fool a large group of people simultaneously. They protect their lair with illusory scenery.
moon: Bonds between these Pokémon are very strong.  It protects the safety of its pack by tricking  its opponents.

sun: Minccino greet each other by grooming one another thoroughly with their tails
moon: These Pokémon prefer a tidy habitat. They are always sweeping and dusting, using their tails as brooms.

sun: Their white fur feels amazing to touch. Their fur repels dust and prevents static electricity from building up.
moon: Cinccino's body is coated in a special oil that helps it deflect attacks, such as punches.

sun: Their ribbonlike feelers increase their psychic power. They are always staring at something.
moon: They intently observe both Trainers and Pokémon. Apparently, they are looking at something that only Gothita can see.

sun: Starlight is the source of their power. At night, they mark star positions by using psychic power to float stones.
moon: According to many old tales, it creates friends for itself by controlling sleeping children on starry nights.

sun: Starry skies thousands of light-years away are visible in the space distorted by their intense psychic power.
moon: They can predict the future from the placement and movement of the stars. They can see Trainers' life spans.

sun: Because their bodies are enveloped in a special liquid, they are fine in any environment, no matter how severe.
moon: They drive away attackers by unleashing psychic power. They can use telepathy to talk with others.

sun: Since they have two divided brains, at times they suddenly try to take two different actions at once.
moon: When their two divided brains think the same thoughts, their psychic power is maximized.

sun: They use psychic power to control their arms, which are made of a special liquid. They can crush boulders psychically.
moon: When Reuniclus shake hands, a network forms between their brains, increasing their psychic power.

sun: When attacked, it uses its feathers to splash water, escaping under cover of the spray.
moon: They are better at swimming than flying, and they happily eat their favorite food, peat moss, as they  dive underwater.

sun: Despite their elegant appearance, they can flap their wings strongly and fly for thousands of miles.
moon: Swanna start to dance at dusk. The one dancing in the middle is the leader of the flock.

sun: Born of an icicle, this Pokémon uses its frosty breath to make ice crystals, causing snow to fall.
moon: It feels pleasantly cool when embraced. This Pokémon is treasured by households in warm regions.

sun: Hot days cause its body to melt. It can be restored by refreezing it, but the process leaves its body slightly warped.
moon: This Pokémon has existed since the Ice Age. It controls particles of ice, freezes its opponents, and then shatters them with a headbutt.

sun: Each of its two heads has a brain, and when they are in agreement, it attacks its enemies by exhaling a violent blizzard.
moon: Even if it loses one of its heads, it can live relatively problem-free. It makes snow clouds inside its body.

sun: Their coloring changes according to the season and can be slightly affected by the temperature and humidity as well.
moon: The turning of the seasons changes the color and scent of this Pokémon's fur. People use it to mark the seasons.

sun: They migrate according to the seasons. People can tell the season by looking at Sawsbuck's horns
moon: They migrate according to the seasons, so some people call Sawsbuck the harbingers of spring.

sun: It glides using its cape-like membrane. Electrical energy scatters from it, shocking its friends and foes alike.
moon: It grills berries and bug Pokémon with electric shocks and makes a meal of them. It usually nests in the holes gouged in trees by Pikipek.

sun: These mysterious Pokémon evolve when they receive electrical stimulation while they are in the same place as Shelmet.
moon: For some reason they evolve when they receive electrical energy while they are attacking Shelmet.

sun: Wearing the shell covering they stole from Shelmet, they defend themselves and attack with two lances.
moon: These Pokémon evolve by wearing the shell covering of a Shelmet. The steel armor protects their whole body.

sun: It lures people in with its Poké Ball pattern, then releases poison spores. Why it resembles a Poké Ball is unknown.
moon: It lures Pokémon with its pattern that looks just like a Poké Ball, then releases poison spores.

sun: They show off their Poké Ball caps to lure prey, but very few Pokémon are fooled by this.
moon: It lures prey close by dancing and waving its arm caps, which resemble Poké Balls, in a swaying motion.

sun: They paralyze prey with poison, then drag them down to their lairs, five miles below the surface.
moon: If its veil-like arms stun and wrap a foe, that foe will be dragged miles below the surface, never to return.

sun: Its body is mostly seawater. It's said there's a castle of ships Jellicent have sunk on the seafloor.
moon: The fate of the ships and crew that wander into Jellicent's habitat: all sunken, all lost, all vanished.

sun: It uses its special mucus to close the wounds of injured Pokémon. The reason for this behavior remains unknown.
moon: They float upon the open sea. Many water Pokémon gather in the area around Alomomola.

sun: Since it can't generate its own electricity, it sticks onto large-bodied Pokémon and absorbs static electricity.
moon: They attach themselves to large-bodied Pokémon and absorbs static electricity, which they store in an electric pouch.

sun: They employ an electrically charged web to trap their prey. While it is immobilized by shock, they leisurely consume it.
moon: When attacked, they create an electric barrier by spitting out many electrically charged threads.

sun: When threatened, it attacks by shooting a barrage of spikes, which gives it a chance to escape by rolling away.
moon: It absorbs the iron it finds in the rock while clinging to the ceiling. It shoots spikes when in danger.

sun: By swinging around its three spiky feelers and shooting spikes, it can obliterate an opponent.
moon: They attach themselves to cave ceilings, firing steel spikes at targets passing beneath them.

sun: Interlocking two bodies and spinning around generates the energy they need to live.
moon: The two minigears that mesh together are predetermined. Each will rebound from other minigears without meshing.

sun: By changing the direction in which it rotates, it communicates its feeling to others. When angry, it rotates faster.
moon: A minigear and big gear comprise its body. If the minigear it launches at a foe doesn't return, it will die.

sun: The gear with the red core is rotated at high speed for a rapid energy charge.
moon: Its red core functions as an energy tank. It fires the charged energy through its spikes into an area.

sun: While one alone doesn't have much power, a chain of many Tynamo can be as powerful as lightning.
moon: One alone can emit only a trickle of electricity, so a group of them gathers to unleash a powerful electric shock.

sun: It wraps itself around its prey and paralyzes it with electricity from the round spots on its sides. Then it chomps.
moon: These Pokémon have a big appetite. When they spot their prey, they attack it and paralyze it with electricity.

sun: With their sucker mouths, they suck in prey. Then they use their fangs to shock the prey with electricity.
moon: They crawl out of the ocean using their arms. They will attack prey on shore and immediately drag it into the ocean.

sun: It uses its strong psychic power to squeeze its opponent's brain, causing unendurable headaches.
moon: Rumors of its origin are linked to a UFO crash site in the desert 50 years ago.

sun: Apparently, it communicates by flashing its three fingers, but those patterns haven't been decoded.
moon: It uses psychic power to control an opponent's brain and tamper with its memories.

sun: While shining a light and pretending to be a guide, it leeches off the life force of any who follow it.
moon: Litwick shines a light that absorbs the life energy of people and Pokémon, which becomes the fuel that it burns.

sun: The spirits it absorbs fuel its baleful fire. It hangs around hospitals waiting for people to pass on.
moon: It arrives near the moment of death and steals spirit from the body.

sun: Being consumed in Chandelure's flame burns up the spirit, leaving the body behind.
moon: The spirits burned up in its ominous flame lose their way and wander this world forever.

sun: They use their tusks to crush the berries they eat. Repeated regrowth makes their tusks strong and sharp.
moon: They mark their territory by leaving gashes in trees with their tusks. If a tusk breaks, a new one grows in quickly.

sun: Their tusks can shatter rocks. Territory battles between Fraxure can be intensely violent.
moon: A broken tusk will not grow back, so it diligently sharpens its tusks on river rocks after the end of a battle.

sun: They are kind but can be relentless when defending territory. They challenge foes with tusks that can cut steel.
moon: Their sturdy tusks will stay sharp even if used to cut steel beams. These Pokémon are covered in hard armor.

sun: Its nose is always running. It sniffs the snot back up because the mucus provides the raw material for its moves.
moon: Their snot is a barometer of health. When healthly, their snot is sticky and the power of their ice moves increases.

sun: They love the cold seas of the north. They create pathways across the ocean waters by freezing their own breath.
moon: It freezes its breath to create fangs and claws of ice to fight with. Cold northern areas are its habitat.

sun: They are born in snow clouds. They use chains made of ice crystals to capture prey.
moon: They are composed of ice crystals. They capture prey with chains of ice, freezing the prey at -148 degrees Fahrenheit.

sun: When it and Karrablast are together, and both receive electrical stimulation, they both evolve.
moon: It evolves when bathed in an electric-like energy along with Karrablast. The reason is still unknown.

sun: Having removed its heavy shell, it becomes very light and can fight with ninja-like movements.
moon: When its body dries out, it weakens. So, to prevent dehydration, it wraps itself in many layers of thin membrane.

sun: Its skin is very hard, so it is unhurt even if stepped on by sumo wrestlers. It smiles when transmitting electricity.
moon: It conceals itself in the mud of the seashore. Then it waits. When prey touch it, it delivers a jolt of electricity.

sun: It takes pride in the speed at which it can use moves. What it loses in power, it makes up for in quantity.
moon: In fights, they dominate with onslaughts of flowing, continuous attacks. With their sharp claws, they cut enemies.

sun: It wields the fur on its arms like a whip. Its arm attacks come with such rapidity that they cannot ever be seen.
moon: Using the long fur on its arms like whips, it launches into combo attacks that, once started, no one can stop.

sun: It races through narrow caves, using its sharp claws to catch prey. The skin on its face is harder than a rock.
moon: It warms its body by absorbing sunlight with its wings. When its body temperature falls, it can no longer move.

sun: The energy that burns inside it enables it to move, but no one has yet been able to identify this energy.
moon: Ancient science fashioned this Pokémon from clay. It's been active for thousands of years.

sun: It is said that Golurk were ordered to protect people and Pokémon by the ancient people who made them.
moon: It flies across the sky at Mach speeds. Removing the seal on its chest makes its internal energy go out of control.

sun: Blades comprise this Pokémon's entire body.  If battling dulls the blades, it sharpens them on stones by the river.
moon: Ignoring their injuries, groups attack by sinking the blades that cover their bodies into their prey.

sun: The pitiless Pokémon commands a group of Pawniard to hound prey into immobility. It then moves in to finish the prey off.
moon: Bisharp pursues prey in the company of a large group of Pawniard. Then Bisharp finishes off the prey.

sun: They charge wildly and headbutt everything. Their headbutts have enough destructive force to derail a train.
moon: Their fluffy fur absorbs damage, even if they strike foes with a fierce headbutt.

sun: They pick fights indiscriminately. They grow stronger and more powerful each time they faint or are injured.
moon: With its sharp claws, this Pokémon pierces its prey, and then it pecks at them. Although it also consumes berries, it’s a carnivore at heart.

sun: With its brave disposition, it fears nothing—not even death. Ancient Alolan people respected it, referring to it as “the hero of the sky.”
moon: It’s thought that people disturbed their habitats in the past, so Braviary banded together to fight back.

sun: It protects its plump posterior with the bones of prey it has consumed. As it grows, it  replaces the bones.
moon: It can’t fly yet and must wait until its wings have developed more. Since it’s still at a playful age, it hops around friskily.

sun: They adorn themselves beautifully with bones. This is supposedly an effort to attract males, but no male Mandibuzz have ever been found.
moon: It circles in the sky, keeping a keen eye out for Pokémon in a weakened state. Its choicest food is Cubone.

sun: Using their very hot, flame-covered tongues, they burn through Durant's steel bodies and consume their insides.

sun: Individuals each play different roles in driving Heatmor, their natural predator, away from their colony.

sun: The heads on their arms do not have brains. They use all three heads to consume and destroy everything.

sun: Said to have been born from the sun, it spews fire from its horns and encases itself in a cocoon of fire when it evolves.
moon: The base of volcanoes is where they make their homes. They shoot fire from their five horns to repel attacking enemies.

sun: A sea of fire engulfs the surroundings of their battles, since they use their six wings to scatter their ember scales.
moon: When volcanic ash darkened the atmosphere, it is said that Volcarona's fire provided a replacement for the sun.

sun: It has a body and heart of steel. Its glare is sufficient to make even an unruly Pokémon obey it.
moon: It has a body and heart of steel. It worked with its allies to punish people when they hurt Pokémon.

sun: Its charge is strong enough to break through a giant castle wall in one blow. This Pokémon is spoken of in legends.
moon: Spoken of in legend, this Pokémon used its phenomenal power to destroy a castle in its effort to protect Pokémon.

sun: Its head sprouts horns as sharp as blades. Using whirlwind-like movements, it confounds and swiftly cuts opponents.
moon: Legends say this Pokémon confounded opponents with its swift movements.

sun: The lower half of its body is wrapped in a cloud of energy. It zooms through the sky at 200 mph.
moon: Tornadus expels massive energy from its tail, causing severe storms. Its power is great enough to blow houses away.

sun: The lower half of its body is wrapped in a cloud of energy. It zooms through the sky at 200 mph.

sun: The spikes on its tail discharge immense bolts of lightning. It flies around the Unova region firing off lightning bolts.
moon: As it flies around, it shoots lightning all over the place and causes forest fires. It is therefore disliked.

sun: The spikes on its tail discharge immense bolts of lightning. It flies around the Unova region firing off lightning bolts.

sun: This legendary Pokémon can scorch the world with fire. It helps those who want to build a world of truth.
moon: When Reshiram's tail flares, the heat energy moves the atmosphere and changes the world's weather.

sun: This legendary Pokémon can scorch the world with lightning. It assists those who want to build an ideal world.
moon: Concealing itself in lightning clouds, it flies throughout the Unova region. It creates electricity in its tail.

sun: Lands visited by Landorus grant such bountiful crops that it has been hailed as “The Guardian of the Fields."
moon: From the forces of lightning and wind, it creates energy to give nutrients to the soil and make the land abundant.

sun: It crosses the world, running over the surfaces of oceans and rivers. It appears at scenic waterfronts.
moon: When it is resolute, its body fills with power and it becomes swifter. Its jumps are then too fast to follow.

sun: The melodies sung by Meloetta have the power to make Pokémon that hear them happy or sad.
moon: Its melodies are sung with a special vocalization method that can control the feelings of those who hear it.

sun: This ancient bug Pokémon was altered by Team Plasma. They upgraded the cannon on its back.
moon: This Pokémon existed 300 million years ago. Team Plasma altered it and attached a cannon to its back.

sun: The quills on its head are usually soft. When it flexes them, the points become so hard and sharp that they can pierce rock.
moon: Such a thick shell of wood covers its head and back that even a direct hit from a truck wouldn't faze it.

sun: It relies on its sturdy shell to deflect predators' attacks. It counterattacks with its sharp quills.
moon: They strengthen their lower bodies by running into one another. They are very kind and won't start fights.

sun: Its Tackle is forceful enough to flip a 50-ton tank. It shields its allies from danger with its own body.
moon: When it takes a defensive posture with its fists guarding its face, it could withstand a bomb blast.

sun: Eating a twig fills it with energy,  and its roomy ears give vent to air  hotter than 390 degrees Fahrenheit.
moon: As it walks, it munches on a twig in place of a snack. It intimidates opponents by puffing hot air out of its ears.

sun: It has a twig stuck in its tail. With  friction from its tail fur, it sets the  twig on fire and launches into battle.
moon: When the twig is plucked from its tail, friction sets the twig alight. The flame is used to send signals to its allies.

sun: It gazes into the flame at the tip of its branch to achieve a focused state, which allows it to see into the future.
moon: Using psychic power, it generates a fiery vortex of 5,400 degrees Fahrenheit, incinerating foes swept into this whirl of flame.

sun: It secretes flexible bubbles from its chest and back. The bubbles reduce the damage it would otherwise take when attacked.
moon: It protects its skin by covering its body in delicate bubbles. Beneath its happy-go-lucky air, it keeps a watchful eye on its surroundings.

sun: It can throw bubble-covered pebbles with precise control, hitting empty cans up to a hundred feet away.
moon: Its swiftness is unparalleled. It can scale a tower of more than 2,000 feet in a minute's time.

sun: It creates throwing stars out of compressed water. When it spins them and throws them at high speed, these stars can split metal in two.
moon: It appears and vanishes with a ninja's grace. It toys with its enemies using swift movements, while slicing them with throwing stars of sharpest water.

sun: It creates throwing stars out of compressed water. When it spins them and throws them at high speed, these stars can split metal in two.
moon: It appears and vanishes with a ninja's grace. It toys with its enemies using swift movements, while slicing them with throwing stars of sharpest water.

sun: They use their large ears to dig burrows.  They will dig the whole night through.
moon: It has ears like shovels. Digging holes strengthens its ears so much that they can sever thick roots effortlessly.

sun: With their powerful ears, they can heft boulders of a ton or more with ease. They can be a big help at construction sites.
moon: As powerful as an excavator, its ears can reduce dense bedrock to rubble. When it's finished digging, it lounges lazily.

sun: This amiable Pokémon is easy to train. But when battle is joined, it shows its ferocious side.
moon: When it’s excited, its temperature can double, spiking hormone production in its body.

sun: From its beak, it fires embers at its prey. Once it has caught them, it grills them at high heat before feasting upon them.
moon: It will not tolerate other Fletchinder entering its territory, which has a radius of several miles.

sun: Its favorite foods are Wingull and Pikipek. It attacks with a powerful kick and grasps them firmly in its talons.
moon: It zooms directly at its prey at flight speeds of close to 310 mph, while fiery embers scatter from gaps in its feathers.

sun: When under attack from bird Pokémon, it spews a poisonous black powder that causes paralysis on contact.
moon: The powder that covers its body regulates its temperature, so it can live in any region or climate.

sun: It lives hidden within thicket shadows. When predators attack, it quickly bristles the fur  covering its body in an effort to threaten them.
moon: The beaks of bird Pokémon can't begin to scratch its stalwart body. To defend itself, it spews powder.

sun: Vivillon with many different patterns are  found all over the world. These patterns  are affected by the climate of their habitat.
moon: The patterns on this Pokémon's wings depend on the climate and topography of its habitat. It scatters colorful scales.

sun: The stronger the opponent it faces, the more heat surges from its mane and the more power flows through its body.
moon: They set off on their own from their pride and live by themselves to become stronger. These hot-blooded Pokémon are quick to fight.

sun: The male with the largest mane of fire is the leader of the pride.
moon: With fiery breath of more than 10,000 degrees Fahrenheit, they viciously threaten any challenger. The females protect the pride's cubs.

sun: It draws out and controls the hidden power of flowers. The flower Flabébé holds is most likely part of its body.
moon: When it finds a flower it likes, it dwells on that flower its whole life long. It floats in the wind's embrace with an untroubled heart.

sun: It flutters around fields of flowers and cares for flowers that are starting to wilt. It draws out the hidden power of flowers to battle.
moon: When the flowers of a well-tended flower bed bloom, it appears and celebrates with an elegant dance.

sun: It flutters around fields of flowers and cares for flowers that are starting to wilt. It draws out the hidden power of flowers to battle.
moon: When the flowers of a well-tended flower bed bloom, it appears and celebrates with an elegant dance.

sun: It claims exquisite flower gardens as its territory, and it obtains power from basking in the energy emitted by flowering plants.
moon: In times long past, governors of castles would invite Florges to create flower gardens to embellish the castle domains.

sun: Thought to be one of the first Pokémon to live in harmony with humans, it has a placid disposition.
moon: If it has sunshine and water, it doesnt need to eat, because it can generate energy from the leaves on its back.

sun: It can tell how its Trainer is feeling by subtle shifts in the grip on its horns. This empathic sense lets them run as if one being.
moon: They inhabit mountainous regions. The leader of the herd is decided by a battle of clashing horns.

sun: It grows up imitating the behavior of Pangoro, which it looks up to as a leader.
moon: There’s no point to the leaf in its mouth, aside from an effort to look cool. It’s mischievous, so it’s not well suited to inexperienced Trainers.

sun: It boasts superb physical strength. Those who wish to become Pangoro’s Trainer have no choice but to converse with their fists.
moon: From the slight twitches of its bamboo leaf, it deduces its opponent’s movements. It’s eager to tussle but kindhearted toward its companions.

sun: Trimming its fluffy fur not only makes  it more elegant but also increases the  swiftness of its movements.
moon: Historically, in the Kalos region, these Pokémon were the designated guardians of the king.

sun: The organ that emits its intense psychic power is sheltered by its ears to keep power from leaking out.
moon: It has enough psychic energy to blast everything within 300 feet of itself, but it has no control over its power.

sun: When in danger, it raises its ears and releases enough psychic power to grind a 10-ton truck into dust.

sun: When in danger, it raises its ears and releases enough psychic power to grind a 10-ton truck into dust.

sun: Apparently this Pokémon is born when a departed spirit inhabits a sword. It attaches itself to people and drinks their life force.
moon: If anyone dares to grab its hilt, it wraps a blue cloth around that person's arm and drains that person's life energy completely.

sun: When Honedge evolves, it divides into two swords, which cooperate via telepathy to coordinate attacks and slash their enemies to ribbons.
moon: The complex attack patterns of its two swords are unstoppable, even for an opponent greatly accomplished at swordplay.

sun: Generations of kings were attended by these Pokémon, which used their spectral power to manipulate and control people and Pokémon.
moon: Apparently, it can detect innate qualities of leadership. According to legend, whoever it recognizes is destined to become king.

sun: It devises various scents, pleasant and unpleasant, and emits scents that its enemies dislike in order to gain an edge in battle.

sun: To entangle its opponents in battle, it extrudes  white threads as sweet and sticky as cotton candy.

sun: It can distinguish the faintest of scents. It puts its sensitive sense of smell to use by helping pastry chefs in their work.
moon: Its sense of smell is 100 million times better than a human's, so even the faintest scent tells it about everything in the area. It's like it can see with its nose!

sun: Opponents who stare at the flashing of the  light-emitting spots on its body become dazed and lose their will to fight.
moon: It flashes the light-emitting spots on its body, which drains its opponent's will to fight. It takes the opportunity to scuttle away and hide.

sun: It wields the most compelling hypnotic powers of any Pokémon, and it forces others to do whatever it wants.

sun: Two Binacle live together on one rock. When they fight, one of them will move to a different rock.

sun: When they evolve, two Binacle multiply into seven. They fight with the power of seven Binacle.

sun: Camouflaged as rotten kelp, they spray liquid poison on prey that approaches unawares and then finish it off.

sun: Their poison is strong enough to eat through the hull of a tanker, and they spit it indiscriminately at anything that enters their territory.

sun: They knock down flying prey by firing  compressed water from their massive  claws like shooting a pistol.

sun: Their enormous claws launch cannonballs of water powerful enough to pierce tanker hulls.

sun: They make their home in deserts. They can  generate their energy from basking in the sun,  so eating food is not a requirement.

sun: They flare their frills and generate energy. A single Heliolisk can generate sufficient electricity to power a skyscraper.

sun: This Pokémon was restored from a fossil. If something happens that it doesn't like, it throws a tantrum and runs wild.

sun: Thanks to its gargantuan jaws, which could shred thick metal plates as if they were paper, it was invincible in the ancient world it once inhabited.
moon: Nothing could stop this Pokémon 100 million years ago, so it behaved like a king.

sun: This ancient Pokémon was restored  from part of its body that had been  frozen in ice for over 100 million years.

sun: The diamond-shaped crystals on its body expel air as cold as -240 degrees Fahrenheit, surrounding its enemies and encasing them in ice.

sun: Its ribbonlike feelers give off an aura that weakens hostility in its prey, causing them to let down their guard. Then it attacks.

sun: This even-tempered Pokémon has a habit of collecting keys. It will sneak into people’s homes to steal their keys.

sun: These Pokémon are stumps possessed by the spirits of children who died in the forest. Their cries sound like eerie screams.

sun: Its ice-covered body is as hard as steel. Its cumbersome frame crushes anything that stands in its way.
moon: The way several Bergmite huddle on its back makes it look like an aircraft carrier made of ice.

sun: They live in pitch-black caves. Their enormous ears can emit ultrasonic waves of 200,000 hertz.

sun: They fly around on moonless nights and attack careless prey. Nothing can beat them in a battle in the dark.

sun: Legends say it can share eternal life. It slept for a thousand years in the form of a tree before its revival.
moon: When the horns on its head shine in seven colors, it is said to be sharing everlasting life.

sun: When this legendary Pokémon's wings and tail feathers spread wide and glow red, it absorbs the life force of living creatures.
moon: When its life comes to an end, it absorbs the life energy of every living thing and turns into a cocoon once more.

sun: When the Kalos region's ecosystem falls into disarray, it appears and reveals its secret power.

sun: It expels its internal steam from the arms on its back. It has enough power to blow away a mountain.
moon: It lets out billows of steam and disappears into the dense fog. It's said to live in mountains where humans do not tread.

sun: This wary Pokémon uses photosynthesis to store up energy during the day, while becoming active at night.
moon: Silently it glides, drawing near its targets. Before they even notice it, it begins to pelt them with vicious kicks.

sun: A bit of a dandy, it spends its free time preening its wings. Its preoccupation with any dirt on its plumage can leave it unable to battle.
moon: It throws sharp feathers called blade quills at enemies or prey. It seldom misses.

sun: It fires arrow quills from its wings with such precision, they can pierce a pebble at distances over a hundred yards.
moon: Although basically cool and cautious, when it’s caught by surprise, it’s seized by panic.

sun: While grooming itself, it builds up fur inside its stomach. It sets the fur alight and spews fiery attacks, which change based on how it coughs.
moon: It doesn’t allow its emotions to be easily seen. Earning its trust takes time. It prefers solitude.

sun: At its throat, it bears a bell of fire. The bell rings brightly whenever this Pokémon spits fire.
moon: It boasts powerful front legs. With a single punch, it can bend an iron bar right over.

sun: This Pokémon has a violent, selfish disposition. If it’s not in the mood to listen, it will ignore its Trainer’s orders with complete nonchalance.
moon: After hurling ferocious punches and flinging furious kicks, it finishes opponents off by spewing fire from around its navel.

sun: This Pokémon snorts body fluids from its nose, blowing balloons to smash into its foes. It’s famous for being a hard worker.
moon: This Pokémon can control water bubbles. It practices diligently so it can learn to make big bubbles.

sun: A skillful dancer, it creates a sequence of water balloons as it dances, and briskly bombards its enemies.
moon: It cares deeply for its companions. When its Trainer is feeling down, it performs a cheery dance to try and help.

sun: It controls its water balloons with song. The melody is learned from others of its kind and is passed down from one generation to the next.
moon: Its singing voice is its chief weapon in battle. This Pokémon’s Trainer must prioritize the daily maintenance of its throat at all costs.

sun: It can peck at a rate of 16 times a second to drill holes in trees. It uses the holes for food storage and for nesting.
moon: This Pokémon feeds on berries, whose leftover seeds become the ammunition for the attacks it fires off from its mouth.

sun: It eats berries and stores their seeds in its beak. When it encounters enemies or prey, it fires off all the seeds in a burst.
moon: By bending its beak, it can produce a variety of calls and brand itself a noisy nuisance for its neighbors.

sun: When it battles, its beak heats up. The temperature can easily exceed 212 degrees Fahrenheit, causing severe burns when it hits.
moon: Within its beak, its internal gas ignites, explosively launching seeds with enough power to pulverize boulders.

sun: With its sharp fangs, it will bite anything. It did not originally live in Alola but was imported from another region.
moon: It wanders around in a never-ending search for food. At dusk, it collapses from exhaustion and falls asleep on the spot.

sun: When it finds a trace of its prey, it patiently stakes out the location...but it’s always snoozing by nightfall.
moon: It adores having Rattata and Raticate for dinner, but as it’s diurnal, it never encounters them. This Pokémon boasts incredible patience.

sun: Its strong jaw enables it to scrape trees and slurp out the sap. It normally lives underground.
moon: They often gather near places frequented by electric Pokémon in order to avoid being attacked by bird Pokémon.

sun: Its body is capable of storing electricity. On camping trips, people are grateful to have one around.
moon: From the food it digests, it generates electricity, and it stores this energy in its electric sac.

sun: It zips around, on sharp lookout for an opening. It concentrates electrical energy within its large jaws and uses it to zap its enemies.
moon: It produces electricity via an electrical organ in its abdomen. It overwhelms bird Pokémon with shocking beams of electrical energy.

sun: While guarding its weak points with its pincers, it looks for an opening and unleashes punches. When it loses, it foams at the mouth and faints.
moon: It punches so much, its pincers often come off from overuse, but they grow back quickly. What little meat they contain is rich and delicious.

sun: It aimed for the top but got lost and ended up on a snowy mountain. Being forced to endure the cold, this Pokémon evolved and grew fur.
moon: It just throws punches indiscriminately. In times of desperation, it can lop off its own pincers and fire them like rockets.

sun: It beats its wings together to create fire. As it moves in the steps of its beautiful dance, it bathes opponents in intense flames.
moon: This Oricorio has sipped red nectar. Its passionate dance moves cause its enemies to combust in both body and mind.

sun: It feeds on the nectar and pollen of flowers. Because it’s able to sense auras, it can identify which flowers are about to bloom.
moon: Myriads of Cutiefly flutter above the heads of people who have auras resembling those of flowers.

sun: It rolls up pollen into puffs. It makes many different varieties, some used as food and others used in battle.
moon: Some of Ribombee’s pollen puffs are highly nutritious. They are sometimes sold as supplements.

sun: It’s considered to be a good Pokémon for beginners because of its friendliness, but its disposition grows rougher as it grows up.
moon: This Pokémon has lived with people since times long ago. It can sense when its Trainer is in the dumps and will stick close by its Trainer’s side.

sun: Its quick movements confuse its enemies. Well equipped with claws and fangs, it also uses the sharp rocks in its mane as weapons.

sun: It plunges the poison spike on its head into its prey. When the prey has weakened, Mareanie deals the finishing blow with its 10 tentacles.
moon: It’s found crawling on beaches and seafloors. The coral that grows on Corsola’s head is as good as a five-star banquet to this Pokémon.

sun: Toxapex crawls along the ocean floor on its 12 legs. It leaves a trail of Corsola bits scattered in its wake.
moon: Those attacked by Toxapex’s poison will suffer intense pain for three days and three nights. Post-recovery, there will be some aftereffects.

sun: The mud stuck to Mudbray’s hooves enhances its grip and its powerful running gait.
moon: It has a stubborn, individualistic disposition. Eating dirt, making mud, and playing in the mire all form part of its daily routine.

sun: It spits a mud that provides resistance to both wind and rain, so the walls of old houses were often coated with it.
moon: Its heavy, mud-covered kicks are its best means of attack, and it can reduce large trucks to scrap without breaking a sweat.

sun: It crawls onto the land in search of food. Its water bubble allows it to breathe and protects its soft head.
moon: When it comes across enemies or potential prey, this Pokémon smashes its water-bubble-covered head into them.

sun: It delivers headbutts with the water bubble on its head. Small Pokémon get sucked into the bubble, where they drown.
moon: Despite what its appearance suggests, it cares for others. If it finds vulnerable, weak Pokémon, it protectively brings them into its water bubble.

sun: During the day, it sleeps and soaks up light. When night falls, it walks around looking for a safer place to sleep.
moon: They give off a sweet and refreshing scent. Cutiefly often gather near the tall grass where Fomantis are hiding.

sun: It requires a lot of effort to maintain Lurantis’s vivid coloring, but some collectors enjoy this work and treat it as their hobby.
moon: It fires beams from its sickle-shaped petals. These beams are powerful enough to cleave through thick metal plates.

sun: It scatters spores that flicker and glow. Anyone seeing these lights falls into a deep slumber.
moon: As it drowses the day away, it nourishes itself by sucking from tree roots. It wakens at the fall of night, wandering off in search of a new tree.

sun: Forests where Shiinotic live are treacherous to enter at night. People confused by its strange lights can never find their way home again.
moon: It emits flickering spores that cause drowsiness. When its prey succumb to sleep, this Pokémon feeds on them by sucking in their energy.

sun: It burns its bodily fluids to create a poisonous gas. When its enemies become disoriented from inhaling the gas, it attacks them.
moon: Volcanoes or dry, craggy places are its home. It emanates a sweet-smelling poisonous gas that attracts bug Pokémon, then attacks them.

sun: For some reason, only females have been found. It creates a reverse harem of male Salandit that it lives with.
moon: Filled with pheromones, its poisonous gas can be diluted to use in the production of luscious perfumes.

sun: Despite its adorable appearance, when it gets angry and flails about, its arms and legs could knock a pro wrestler sprawling.
moon: A touch from anyone except a known friend sends it into a surging frenzy. It’s an incredibly dangerous Pokémon.

sun: This immensely dangerous Pokémon possesses overwhelming physical strength. Its habitat is generally off-limits.
moon: This Pokémon has the habit of hugging its companions. Many Trainers have left this world after their spines were squashed by its hug.

sun: A delectable aroma pours from its body. They are often swallowed whole by Toucannon lured by that wafting deliciousness.
moon: Although it’s too sugary for human consumption, Bounsweet’s sweat can be watered down into a juice with just the right amount of sweetness.

sun: The sepals on its head developed to protect its body. These are quite hard, so even if pecked by bird Pokémon, this Pokémon is totally fine.
moon: This Pokémon is always bouncing around energetically. Other Pokémon are attracted by its lively appearance and pleasant aroma.

sun: Its long, striking legs aren’t just for show but to be used to kick with skill. In victory, it shows off by kicking the defeated, laughing boisterously.
moon: A Pokémon known for the beauty of its well-shaped legs, it sometimes appears as a mascot in advertisements for beauty salons.

sun: It attaches flowers to its highly nutritious vine. This revitalizes the flowers, and they give off an aromatic scent.
moon: Baths prepared with the flowers from its vine have a relaxing effect, so this Pokémon is a hit with many people.

sun: Known for its extreme intelligence, this Pokémon will look down on inexperienced Trainers, so it’s best suited to veteran Trainers.
moon: Deep in the jungle, high in the lofty canopy, this Pokémon abides. On rare occasions, it shows up at the beach to match wits with Slowking.

sun: They form groups of roughly 20 individuals. Their mutual bond is remarkable—they will never let down a comrade.
moon: They battle with hard berries for weapons. Their techniques are passed from the boss to the group, generation upon generation.

sun: This Pokémon is a coward. As it desperately dashes off, the flailing of its many legs leaves a sparkling clean path in its wake.
moon: Its habitat varies from beaches to seabeds. A natural scavenger, it will gleefully chow down on anything edible, no matter how rotten.

sun: With a flashing slash of its giant sharp claws, it cleaves seawater—or even air—right in two.
moon: It battles skillfully with its six arms, but spends most of its time peacefully meditating in caves deep beneath the sea.

sun: Born from a sand mound playfully built by a child, this Pokémon embodies the grudges of the departed.
moon: It takes control of anyone who puts a hand in its mouth. And so it adds to the accumulation of its sand-mound body.

sun: Possessed people controlled by this Pokémon transformed its sand mound into a castle. As it evolved, its power to curse grew ever stronger.
moon: Buried beneath the castle are masses of dried-up bones from those whose vitality it has drained.

sun: It lives in shallow seas, such as areas near a beach. It can eject its internal organs, which it uses to engulf its prey or battle enemies.
moon: These Pokémon line the beaches. The sticky mucous that covers their bodies can be used to soothe sunburned skin. How convenient!

sun: The heavy control mask it wears suppresses its intrinsic capabilities. This Pokémon has some hidden special power.
moon: Due to the danger that this synthetic Pokémon may go on a rampage, it wears a control mask to restrain its power.

sun: It destroyed its own control mask. It has become capable of changing its type by equipping special memories.
moon: Upon awakening, its RKS System is activated. By employing specific memories, this Pokémon can adapt its type to confound its enemies.

sun: Originally making its home in the ozone layer, it hurtles to the ground when the shell enclosing its body grows too heavy.
moon: Strong impacts can knock it out of its shell. This Pokémon was born from mutated nanoparticles.

sun: Originally making its home in the ozone layer, it hurtles to the ground when the shell enclosing its body grows too heavy.
moon: Strong impacts can knock it out of its shell. This Pokémon was born from mutated nanoparticles.

sun: It is born asleep, and it dies asleep. All its movements are apparently no more than the results of it tossing and turning in its dreams.
moon: The log it holds was given to it by its parents at birth. It has also been known to cling to the arm of a friendly Trainer.

sun: The shell on its back is chemically unstable and explodes violently if struck. The hole in its stomach is its weak point.
moon: It gushes fire and poisonous gases from its nostrils. Its dung is an explosive substance and can be put to various uses.

sun: The spiny fur on its back is normally at rest. When this Pokémon becomes agitated, its fur stands on end and stabs into its attackers.
moon: The long hairs on its back act as lightning rods. The bolts of lightning it attracts are stored as energy in its electric sac.

sun: Its actual appearance is unknown. A scholar who saw what was under its rag was overwhelmed by terror and died from the shock.
moon: A lonely Pokémon, it conceals its terrifying appearance beneath an old rag so it can get closer to people and other Pokémon.

sun: When it unleashes its psychic power from the protuberance on its head, the grating sound of grinding teeth echoes through the area.
moon: It stuns its prey with psychokinesis and then grinds them to mush with its strong teeth. Even Shellder’s shell is no match for it.

sun: It has a compassionate personality, but if it is angered, it completely destroys its surroundings with its intense breath.
moon: This Pokémon is friendly to people and loves children most of all. It comes from deep in the mountains to play with children it likes in town.

sun: Swinging its massive anchor, it can KO Wailord in a single blow. What appears to be green seaweed is actually its body.
moon: The soul of seaweed adrift in the waves became reborn as this Pokémon. It maintains itself with new infusions of seabed detritus and seaweed.

sun: It expresses its feelings by smacking its scales. Metallic sounds echo through the tall mountains where Jangmo-o lives.

sun: It leaps at its prey with a courageous shout. Its scaly punches tear its opponents to shreds.

sun: When it spots enemies, it threatens them by jingling the scales on its tail. Weak opponents will crack and flee in panic.
moon: Its rigid scales function as offense and defense. In the past, its scales were processed and used to make weapons and other commodities.

sun: This guardian deity of Melemele is brimming with curiosity. It summons thunderclouds and stores their lightning inside its body.

sun: This guardian deity of Akala is guilelessly cruel. The fragrant aroma of flowers is the source of its energy.

sun: It pulls large trees up by the roots and swings them around. It causes vegetation to grow, and then it absorbs energy from the growth.

sun: Its body is gaseous and frail. It slowly grows as it collects dust from the atmosphere.

sun: Motionless as if dead, its body is faintly warm to the touch. In the distant past, it was called the cocoon of the stars.
moon: There’s something accumulating around the black core within its hard shell. People think this Pokémon may come from another world.

sun: It is said to live in another world. The intense light it radiates from the surface of its body can make the darkest of nights light up like midday.
moon: This Pokémon is said to be a male evolution of Cosmog. At the activation of its third eye, it departs for another world.

sun: It is said to be a female evolution of Cosmog. When its third eye activates, away it flies to another world.

sun: One of several mysterious Ultra Beasts. People on the street report observing those infested by it suddenly becoming violent.

sun: This Ultra Beast appeared from another world. It shows off its body, but whether that display is a boast or a threat remains unclear.

sun: One of the dangerous Ultra Beasts, it has been spotted running across the land at terrific speeds.

sun: This Ultra Beast came from the Ultra Wormhole. It seems not to attack enemies on its own, but its sharp body is a dangerous weapon in itself.

sun: It has gobbled mountains and swallowed whole buildings, according to reports. It’s one of the Ultra Beasts.
moon: A dangerous Ultra Beast, it appears to be eating constantly, but for some reason its droppings have never been found.

sun: Reminiscent of the Ultra Beasts, this life-form, apparently asleep underground, is thought to have come from another world in ancient times.
moon: Light is apparently the source of its energy. It has an extraordinarily vicious disposition and is constantly firing off laser beams.

sun: Able to conceal itself in shadows, it never appears before humans, so its very existence was the stuff of myth.

sun: This Ultra Beast is well enough liked to be chosen as a first partner in its own world.

sun: It stores hundreds of liters of poisonous liquid inside its body. It is one of the organisms known as UBs.

sun: It slithers toward people. Then, without warning, it triggers the explosion of its own head. Itâ€™s apparently one kind of Ultra Beast.

sun: It electrifies its claws and tears its opponents apart with them. Even if they dodge its attack, theyâ€™ll be electrocuted by the flying sparks.
